ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained a greater knowledge of some semantic theories (cognitive semantics, frame semantics, prototype theory, etc.)
General knowledge of conceptual structures and related theories

I learned Jackendoff's framework of semantic meaning analysis and engaged with several other theories of semantic meaning, including frame semantics and prototype theory. I experienced (on a much smaller scale) the process of linguistic research brainstorming, execution and analysis.
I learned a lot about linguistics and gained skills in scientific research, presenting, and debating ideas.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course was very engaging, and felt the most relevant to my life own knowledge.

Strengths: lively class conversations

Weaknesses: almost everything -- material was extremely disorganized/class did not have good "flow," almost no feedback other than directly meeting with professor (who most often tried to hastily come up with some form of "half-formed" criticisms, which she often went back on later in the semester), professor's communication.
The class requires a lot of participation based on discussions. It was half-structured and how a student engages is important.
Weakness: Unclear expectations (regarding assignments, depth of study, etc.)

I loved the way this course was structured and felt like we all learned a lot!  I wish we sometimes had gotten clearer feedback but our class discussions were so fun and engaging, it made for a great experience.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments:
This was the worst class I have ever taken at Yale -- I would NOT recommend it. I did not enjoy the course (largely because of its disorganization) and I often had issues with the professor.

I never knew exactly what I was supposed to be learning/doing, despite engaging with the class -- Professor MMP never seemed to give holistic feedback. For example, in the class, we had a project that ran through the course of the semester. There were issues with the first version of the project I submitted that she failed to comment on until I met with her the day before the project was due, which was extremely frustrating and unnecessarily stressful. Furthermore, though she emphasized "approaching things slowly and enjoying the process," ironically, during every conversation I've had with her, it seems like she wants me out of her office as quickly as possible: she interrupts me excessively, often before she even understands what I am even asking, and comes up with hasty feedback which sometimes seems like it is formulated just for the sake of coming up with feedback and, again, getting me out of her office. She is also terrible at grading/giving written feedback -- I received written feedback only on one of three or four MAJOR assignments during the entire semester, and, though routine assignments are graded for completion, I randomly received an 80 on one of them with no comments. 

Additionally, I felt that what the professor wanted was for us simply to regurgitate what she had already been saying. Whenever a criticism was brought up, she never took the time to actually understand it, and often gaslit students into believing that she had addressed their question, even when it had not been fully addressed. (I have also talked to peers about this, some of whom feel similarly.)
If they were interested primarily in the meaning side of linguistics, yes.
Definitely yes - whether or not you've studied linguistics before, everyone can benefit from this course.
